.
This is a companion Thing to my Micro-Adjustable Bare Wire Z End Stop ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23811 ) -- this is actually the way all of my end stops have looked since January.
.
This is about as inexpensive as you can get with your endstops, and yet they've worked flawlessly and predictably for months on end. Each endstop is fashioned from a paperclip, a short piece of copper wire, some electrical tape, and a twisted pair from an old network cable. They are NO (normally open) switches as opposed to NC (normally closed) so you'll need to configure your firmware accordingly, and you don't get the fail-safe you would otherwise get with NC switches -- but the trade off here is in the simplicity of the mechanical action, arguably lower risk of mechanical failure, and the lower vitamin count.

1) Find a paperclip from under the couch cushion or the back of the desk drawer, and an obsolete network cable or telephone cord. 2) Cut the paper clip and shape it into two "L" shapes, and crimp, solder, or tightly wrap the short ends of the L's with the network cable. 3) Poke the long ends through a strip of electrical tape about 3-4mm apart, and tape the assembly down securely onto the end stop holder, making sure the wires won't touch. 4) Tape a short piece of copper wire to the extruder body, print bottom plate, or X end so that it will complete the circuit when it hits the paper clips. 5) Marvel at the simplicity and reliability, and then proceed to upgrade the Z axis end stop to my Micro-Adjustable Bare Wire Z End Stop ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23811 ). I haven't had to do this yet, but you'll probably need to clean the wires at some point to ensure a good connection. A quick scrape with fine sandpaper will probably do the trick. I've been told that paper clips don't conduct electricity. I'm not really sure how to respond to that other than to say that these work great -- perhaps they're coated with a conductor. Legal Disclaimer: The "One-Penny" bit was a guess. You should be able to find someone to give you a paper clip for a penny. If not, I'll gladly send you one if you cover shipping and handling.

comments.text: Normally-open endstop switches are actually more fail-safe, unless you are using both min- and max-endstops.  If an NC switch fails, then the machine will only move in the positive direction for each axis, potentially causing it to run into the max limits of the machine.  If an NO switch fails, the only problem will be when the machine homes at the beginning of a print, and that would be easy to catch.
comments.author: NewPerfection

comments.text: No, NC switches are much safer, as a NC endstop will fail in one way almost all the time (with the rare exception that the contacts weld together, but then something's VERY wrong)
comments.author: NewPerfection

description.text:
My wonderful open-source networked irrigation sprinkler controller betrayed me--the connector to the sprinkler wiring system had pulled loose when someone disturbed the cable, and so for some unknown time it said it was watering my plants, but it wasn't.
I made these clips to hold the connector securely in place.
This fits the original OpenSprinkler and expansion from rayshobby.net, but the new cases currently on offer probably will require some enlarging of the connector opening for these.
Fuse holder Flosser 39150

remixed_from.title: AM8 Electronics Case with Dual mosfet

description.text:
thanks to CPT_Spekkie and Adinin for helping me with feedback :)

i added the .f3d file for thoose willing to make personal changes. IF you make something and put on thingiverse please write my name as original author :)

please always read version reports and use appropriate versions

made this case for a raspberry 3 for AM8.
there is access to audio, HDMI, power and SD card and GPIO against the extruded frame.

there is also an cable duct for use between rasp and electronic case.

needs following:

1pc thumbscrev M4 (self tap)
3pc M5 screws 10mm (4pc if you decide to use the duct)
4pc 2.5mm screws and nuts

keep in mind that the screws for the side to the frame needs a smaller skull sinces the GPIO ports may be in the way.(should be fixed in V5)

printed with supports, my rasp fitted perfectly after i went over the contact holes quickly with a knife to smooth edges.

will be work-in-progress till someone else printed and gave it "ok"

2017-06-19
Version fix:
in V4 alot of fitting was made, made the holes larger for fastening to frame, made the holes for rasp screws coned so they dont collapse during print

2017-06-20
V5, added more space to the powerjack for thoose using phone charger cables.
V6, forgot to remove a small part when i extruded the case.
lid V3 updated so it fits V6

made an cable hider for use between the electornic case and the raspberry. the network cable goes inside the housing and out on the back where the small hole is. have not tested this yet.

there is a cablehouse for thoose using corners from AM8 project. its its 4cm to be put between rasp and electronic case

comments.author: CPT_Spekkie

comments.text: Just finished printing this, and first off, great design. The lid fit is spot on and the whole thing should look great once I get more screws to mount it. The only problem I had was the fit, like spekkie said the audio jack was a bit low and too far back. I don't know if you can tell from my pictures, it just took a bit of carving to make it fit. Also needed a bit more room around the power jack, mine didn't quite fit. It sounds like you have already fixed it though,I'm on my phone so can't check the STL...all in all though, kudos and thanks!
comments.author: Pokelia

comments.text: i added 2 mm on the Z axis of the power jack hole. should be enough.
comments.author: Adinin

comments.text: Looks good, one small point though. the mounting holes don't need to be 6mm. 5.5 is precisely what you would want. Because if you design them 5.5 they will be a little smaller but the screws are normally never bigger then 5mm (M5) so the .5 extra is what you would want. Making it 6 could introduce new problems. Like less plastic for the screw to grab onto.
comments.author: Pokelia

comments.text: good points, i fix it.
comments.author: CPT_Spekkie

comments.text: thanks for the pictures, ill check it out in an hour and make changes!

description.text:
this is to mount the DPS600 psu to the back of the right Z-tower

you need foillowing:
1 amphenol MUSBA51100 port
4 M5 screws for frame (or 6 if you use 2 holders)
4 nuts for mounting in the frame (or six)
2 screws for amphenol mount

hole is an USB port for an amphenol USB port.
on the backside there is a small gap to the frame, this is used to drag the powercables inside the frame.

keep in mind that i do not use the standard fasteners for the frame. if you do, just saw off the edge to make it fit.

will need supports.

one of each is needed, if you feel like it, add the holder twice so you have it tightly secured (i use only one holder).

will be work in progress until someone prints it and says its OK

description.text: If you ever wonder how to impress your robotics teacher, mom and dad or your friends, this is the perfect robot. Its name is Chip-E The Quadruped. It walks on four legs. It previously was a biped which was later converted into a quadruped! It will impress people as it looks complicated yet is very simple to build. You should have a working quadruped in not more than 3 hours after print.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Dreamer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Level your bed before printing. You can print it with a raft, but it gives it a more rough appearence. Look after the print as sometimes if the speed is to fast, the print might not stick onto the print bed.

Inspiration strikes

I just woke up, did my daily chores and went into thingiverse. When I saw the Chip-E Remix Challenge, I felt something wrong. Why should Chip-E always have '2 legs' instead of 4 legs like a quadruped. That is when I got my idea. I immediately started working on my 3d model and produced this work in about 2 hours later.

title: 90mm Storm Water Drain Outlet Flap Hinge

description.text:
18 June -2017: Added 3 photos of an actual completed assembly, ready to be added to a drain pipe. The actual flap is just a piece of offcut acrylic I had lying around but it could be anything.

Where I live we have large pythons and, both to protect the snakes and to keep my pipes flowing, I have flaps on my stormwater drain pipe outlets to prevent snakes, rats and other small critters from entering the pipes. Using a grid on the end of the pipe does not work as grids catch leaves and gets blocked leading to a pipe that fills up, overflows and does not drain as intended.

This hinge is designed to be clamped on to a 90mm PVC storm water pipe with a large hose clamp or sturdy cable tie. There is a hole provided to put a little self tapper through to help the cable tie.(I don't think PVC glue will work) The 90mm pipe needs to be ended with a 45 degree angle ( more or less. See the images). It uses gravity to close the flap, hence the angle. The flap, even though shown as a oval, any rectangular piece of perspex will do as long as it is wider and longer than the opening of your pipe. The flap is bolted from the inside with three 3mm self tappers. (I tried to give an idea of a cable tie placement in the assembled picture - the thinnish orange ring around it all on the right hand side. Did not want to spend a big amount of time 3d modeling a cable tie).

What I like to do is to build the whole assembly on a short piece of 90mm pipe (as shown) so I can comfortably work on my workbench. Then, by using a 90mm joiner section, I can simply glue the whole thing on to the end of the actual drainpipe. I know it will cost you a dollar or 2 more but it is much more convenient.

The hinge consists of two 3mm diameter x14mm bolts. The inner hinge hole is 3.2 whilst the outer is 2.9 so the bolts should rotate freely in the inner hole. The reason for using the outer hole to cut thread through is so the device is less sensitive to how tightly you screw the bolts in and also so that if you take the hinge apart, the bolts will be captured by the outer part of the hinge and not simply fall and get lost.

The back of the hinge has been extended with a limit stop to prevent the flap from being opened so far that it will not close on it's own (e.g., wind or very strong water flow). As long as the hinge is not seized and correctly mounted, it will always close.

You will need:
The hinge part-a (the outer hinge section) and part-b (the inner hinge section)
2 off 3mm diameter x14mm pan head stainless steel bolts (for the hinge)
3 off 3mm diameter x5mm stainless steel self tappers (or you could use 10-12mm long bolts and nuts) to secure the flap to the hinge
1 large hose clamp or cable tie to secure the hinge to the pipe (4.8mm wide x 380mm UV stabilised cable tie works fine)
1 off 3mm diameter x5mm stainless steel self tapper (or 10-12mm long bolt and nut) to secure the hinge to the top of the pipe and prevent slipping.

Hints:
First, cut the angle on the pipe. Use a mitre or something to ensure it is flat and around 45 deg.
Assemble the hinge part-a and part-b. With the hinge gin the fully closed position (i.e. as it will be with the pipe closed off) and hold the flap material on the inside of part-a so you can judge how close to the hinge axis you can mount it (affected by flap thickness). Drill the centre hole on the flap accordingly (use about a 3.2mm drill or slightly bigger than the self tappers you will be using). Loosely mount the flap so you can make sure it is straight and will sit flush on the pipe without hindering the hinge. Now you can mark the other 2 holes. Dis-assemble and drill the other two holes. Now you can mount the flap making sure to screw from the flap side into part-a (to minimise protrusions in the pipe that can catch on debris).
Now, hold the whole assembly on the pipe so you can move it back and forth till the flap seal on the pipe is perfect. Mark the location of the hole. Remove the hinge and drill the pipe. Use a 3.2 mm if you will be using a bolt and nut as I have or 2-2.5mm or so if you will be using a self tapper from the top. If you are using a bolt, insert it from the inside and tighten the nut from the top with a long-nose plier.

title: Fidget Spinner Cube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Fidget Spinner Cube.
I saw something similar on the web and decided to design one myself.

Now you can fidget in 3 dimensions!

There are 2 different sets uploaded:
One is the default with basically 0mm tolerance i.e the holes are exactly 22mm
The second one has .05mm tolerance i.e the holes are 22.05mm in diameter.

The caps are also different dimensions to compensate for varying printer tolerances.

https://youtu.be/VkIVaAHuigc
https://youtu.be/sNBpOrHmNd8

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm or 0.2mm

Infill:

35%+

Notes:

I used a 3D honeycomb infill pattern.
It provides a better distribution of mass and reduces vibration.
Just check your top and bottom layer count i.e. 3 top and 3 bottom layers, it will stabilise the spinner.

Hopefully nothing, but maybe a bit of sanding.
The holes are supposed to be tight. Just put the cube on a flat surface and press down to seat the bearings, this also ensures the bearings line up.

I used FreeCAD to design this model.
I created a cube and started to cut out the holes on the sides.
The holes are 7mm deep and have a seat at the bottom so that the 608 bearings all sit at the same height. There is also a fillet at the bottom of each hole so that it can print without supports.

description = Rachel Lancaster

I created my own solar lamp. My plan is to build a solar lamp which can be switched on and off via wifi. To start a project like this you need a solid project platform to build everything up. I created a housing, which can be used for. This lamp is the first step and can be used already for a working simple lamp.
For my first version, I used the following set from ebay. I’m sure there will be other equal kits available in your country.
http://www.ebay.de/itm/352063089252

Unfortunately, the solar cell doesn’t deliver enough Volt to power up 2 AA batteries or more.
It delivers 2 V, perfect would be 5 - 6 Volt to power up a LiPo with 3,7V. This is needed for a esp8266 to use the Wifi functionality.

The battery holder is the following part which I found here on thingiverse https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456900

comments.text: Interesting project...  As I understand it, wifi takes a lot of power compared to other wireless methodologies.  I wonder if it would be better to use a mesh network comprised of NRF24L01's...?  I would the the power consumption would be far less than using an ESP8266 & wifi.
comments.author: wombat991

comments.text:
The good thing, you only need a ESP8266 and a view small components, nothing more. You can put the scatch directly into the ESP8266.
Compared with the NRF24L01 it is much easier. The ESP8266 has a sleeping mode, which is helpfull to save energy. The problem will be to connect to a wifi router needs a lot of power. Not sure if a LiPo will have this power. We will see. It is not tested yet.
But thanks for your interessting suggestion. If it doesn't work with the ESP8266 I will come back to it.

title: Crow Feeder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Adapted from Kitlaan and Tunell this includes the components to make an auger feeder for use with either a 1in or 1.25in Schedule 40 PVC Tee. Included are designs for both sizes for auger, servo mount, and mount for 1 or 2L bottle to hold food, used with a continuous rotation servo (FS5103R Feetech - easily obtained through adafruit, amazon, or directly) and driven by an arduino.

I used this to build my own automated crow behavior box (pictures, code and accessories to be uploaded later).

Auger has been modified from Kitlaan and Tunnell's designs without a need to sand down for either 1in or 1.25in PVC.

description.text: This 2 part thing is designed to hold 8 Octet tips in line @ 9mm center-to-center spacing so that they can be manipulated together (using microtiter plates, etc.) The assembled tip holder includes a bar that can be used to eject the tips. This tool is most useful when manually loading or amine coupling tips off-line in order to save time and protein. The ejection mechanism needs improvement from an ergonomics/functional standpoint. Eventually I hope to make an indexed carrier that will assist in moving the tips from well to well accurately so that the biosensor surface(s) is not damaged by inappropriate contact with a solid object.

Designed in OpenSCAD by Jeff Dantzler & printed in ABS by Metrix in Seattle. Make sure that you print with a high level of infill (80%+) and settings that give very good adhesion of layers. The slender projections are delicate and will break easily at the cone/cylinder junction on low infill (e.g. 50%) prints.
For Taranis X9D with Hall effect Gimbals

author: Auhuber

description.text:
I was making a box/trunk in the old steamer trunk style.  I didn't like the brass corners they had at the hardware store so I printed my own.  
These are for 90 degree corners with a 45 degree chamfer on them.

If your trunk does not have rounded over corners, you'll need to attack it with a plane or a router to get the 45 degree corners this requires.  
This file does not include screw/nail holes.  It is intended that you heat up one of your fasteners and poke the holes where you need them.

This is mostly like any regular gyro toy but has two main differences that make it cool. It is modular and you can assemble it with 4 diferent colors and see how POV (Persistence of Vision) makes its magic creating new colors as you spin it. So print the elipsoid parts in as many diferent colors you have and experiment with POV. It makes a great experimenting magic puzzle for kids as it is easily assembled/unassembled. I designed this for my little nephew's science project at his college, all kids loved it. Part.stl requires baseplate support. Glue the tip if it becames loose. Tip and main axe designed as separate parts to avoid use of supports on this part.

POV is a phenomena involving your eyes. Cells into your retina get the color you see but have a little delay until they 'sees' next color. So when you change rapidly the colors as in the spinning gyro, the cells in your retina make the color mix for you !! This works only for your eyes, not for a camera, don't surprise if you can see colors your camera doesn't.

Will put pics of my builds If my nephew returns them to me (unlikely). So please post a make if you build one and have the time, thanks.

Enjoy.

UPDATE (16-JUN-2017):Increased tolerances for the radial parts to ease kids' play.

An updated version of my Y-Carriage this time with Jonas KÃ¼hling's LM holder. So no more zipties. They come in LM8UU or LM10UU variaties. Choose the one your want and remember to print the corresponding spacers. I uses the LM10x3 version with Misumi LMU-MX10 self lubricating bearings. More pictures here: http://goo.gl/JRg97

You will also need configuration.scad to use the SCAD files. If you have trouble slicing the STLs cleanly, you may want to run them through netfabb. 10mm rod mount and clamp are here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23898 If you are printing the carriage in PLA, I would strongly suggest that you print the spacers in ABS. Especially if your HBP is close to them. IMPORTANT NOTE
lm8x3, lm8x4, lm10x3 and lm10x4 has a smooth rod center to center distance of 98.4mm. This is what i get by measuring with a caliber. This is what i use, YMMV. lm8x3-100, lm8x4-100, lm10x3-100 and lm10x4-100 has the default mendelmax smooth rod center distance of 100mm. I find that the best way to get a butter smooth Y-stage is to install the Y rods into the MM body first (you need the Y rod mounts and clamps), measure the actual distance between the smooth rods, then print your Y-carriage with that exact distance.

comments.text: if they break off easily, then you need to check 2 things,  1.) nozzle temp.  Try up your nozzle temp by 10C and see how it goes,  2.) check your E calibration and filament diameter measurement again, I did a test and found that a 3% difference in filament diameter(1.75 but actual measured dia is 1.70) result in very weak parts no matter how high i set the temperature to.

title: Pokeball spinner for small hands (624Z bearing)

description.text:
My son wanted to have the Pokeball spinner (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2278247), but he's only 6 and a 608Z bearing-based spinner is too large for his hands. I tried scaling the Pokeball spinner down for a 624Z bearing but it's not a linear scale so it wasn't going to look right.

I therefore redrew the design in FreeCAD using a scaled copy of the Pokeball spinner as a guide.

Be aware that this is very small. The centre buttons on the balls are less than 4mm across, so you need to have your printer set up well.

I strongly recommend a 0.1mm layer height if you can do this and an absolute maximum nozzle diameter of 0.4mm. A diameter of 0.2mm would be much better. Also, since this is a spinner it needs weight and strength, so go for a 100% infill.

If you want, you can add three M5 nuts to give it a bit more weight so that it spins better...

The spinner I made was printed in ABS, you may have better results with PLA (but I've only ever printed in ABS).

description.text:
Designed to work with Walpeup's Low Profile Ball-Bearing Printrbot Simple Metal Spool Holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2036443)

I have the Z-axis upgrade for the Printrbot, and my old spool holder sat vertically atop the printer, making it awfully top heavy. So I loved the idea of a horizontal spool holder to lower the center of gravity a bit.

I printed one of Walpeup's out, but unfortunately it didn't work with most of the spools I have from different filament companies.

The central hub (the guide piece) it too big for some of my spools.

The vertically oriented bearings also don't always align with a smooth surface on my spools.

So I designed this simple part to replace the original guide. The upper cylinder is small enough to fit inside all my current spools.

I added a thin flat disc attached to the bottom of the guide piece for the bearings to roll against and ensure smooth operation across many spool types.

You will need to print the SpoolBase part from Walpeup's thing page (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2036443).

I posted the OpenSCAD model, and it would be super easy to adjust if this guide does not quite fit your own spools.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed in PLA. I had some trouble with the edge of the outer disk warping, even on my heated bed with kapton tape and hair spray. I was able to press it flat while it was still flexible.

It might be just an adhesion problem with my own setup, but I'm wondering if I can do something structurally with the model to help reduce warping. Happy to hear any ideas in the comments.

title: Wrist band for Withings Pulse
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I really like my Withings Pulse. The only annoyance is the velcro wristband for using it as a sleep monitor which stopped staying at my wrist at night after a few months as the velcro stopped sticking sufficiently.  
So, let's try this one: I made a clip for emmett's Nano watchband to fix the Pulse to it instead of an iPod Nano. Your can just clip the pulse inside the clip, the button of the pulse is still reachable when it's clipped in. While inside, the heart rate sensor will not work as it cannot see your skin - but it also didn't work well in the velcro band, so I never used it while wearing it with the band.   
Let's hope I will not have to search for my Pulse anymore in the morning as I lost it somewhere in my bed at night...  
Customizer feature is experimental as it's the first time I try this and the code for the clip looks rather ugly. In Customizer, the clip is static except for the tolerance, so watch out if you change the band too much. The rest is the original code from emmett.  
Update: I added a latch STL file for a 20 mm wide and 3 mm thick band (the standard settings in the customizer). It's not perfect, but it works and makes opening and closing of the band much easier.

Just print it, no support needed. Depending on your printer and slicer settings, the Pulse should clip in and out nicely. I used Cura at 100% infill and 0.2 mm layer height on my K8200.  
If you want, you can just print the clip and use emmet's wrist band with the standard settings and it should also fit as I didn't change it.  
You will have to play with the tolerance of the pins to fit to your printer. The assembly STL is at tolerance 0.4 mm which was too tight for my printer. I ended up with 0.5 mm. I also added some test strips with 3 joints each at 0.5, 0.6, 0.7 and 0.8 so you can directly try it out.

description.text:
I have designed a 3D model of a Victorian style hurricane lamp. It holds a small battery-powered tea light. It comes in a number of pieces and screws together. Depending on which pieces you use, the lamp can be tall (26cm if you use all the pieces) or shorter with a combination as shown in the gallery. Tea lights used should not exceed 4cm in diameter.
This is part of an experiment for myself to show that Blender can be used for models that require some precision work. The threads were built in OpenSCAD using the library by aubenc(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8796), but the assembly and design was done in Blender alone,importing the threads when needed. This model was also designed to push my printers further regarding clarity and overhang. None of the pieces require support to print. NOTICE: I finally got around to uploading the swirly base with a whole load less geometry. This should make it easier to work with: swirling_base_decimated.stl this is now just over 5mb. Also, a user requested a version with a 7mm hole down the middle. This has been uploaded too. Sorry for the delay.Been a bit busy xx

PRINTING The components for this model will print without support. As the model is quite large, I recommend you print with a low infill. The models shown in my gallery were printed with .1 and .15 infill. LAMPSHADE The lampshade is a solid model. You will need to print this with 0 infill and no top or bottom layers. This is a far more efficient method than me providing a hollowed out model and allows you to decide how many perimeters you want to use. The lampshade is designed to fit snugly around the light holder, so may require a little twisting to get in place. However, if you don't want to mess with this, fellow Thingiverse user: http://www.thingiverse.com/shiuan/ made a hollowed out version for download: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:840538 Thank you! ASSEMBLY How it fits together is demonstrated in the gallery. You will need to use the light holder with the castle regardless of whether you print and use the shade, otherwise your light will not be held securely.
Please do not use anything more powerful than an LED tea light in this model! Please.

comments.text: I found a slightly easier way and it just seems to work for me.  Grab a roll and do a thin walled print using 1.0 as your extrusion multiplier (this is all assuming you already have dialed in the proper e-steps) and however far off you are is what you will use as your extrusion multiplier.  I do this on every roll and mark on the roll what multiplier to use for that roll.  Say 0.4mm thin wall for a 0.35mm nozzle and out comes 0.42 on the top 3 layers of a thin wall then 0.4/0.42=0.9523 and I use that as my extrusion multiplier.  Do it one more time and repeat the math then write it down on the roll.  I used to do the caliper method but it never was as accurate for me.

comments.author: Quick

comments.text:
Thanks for your feedback. It's my first 'fit together' model (other than the flowers for my coasters) so I appreciate all
comments. So, what did you do to rectify the issue with thread length
and clearance. I am guessing thread length would be easy enough to fix
by cutting the model in something like MeshLab. But what about the
other issue?
comments.author: Quick

comments.text: The threaded base that was too long, was found out after printing, so it was cut with a band saw. For the threads being too tight, I used sand paper and sanded them down about 1/2 way. Again, this was found out after printing. The male threads were easy and the female threads a bit harder. The female threads did not get sanded as much as the male threads.  For something like this type of fit up, a rounded thread works better.  Also if the threads are tight, adding some water or veg oil to the threads and working the threads back and forth help, when threading together.

title: NYLON Derivative of the Printable 608 Ball Bearing

description.text:
These are the stl files used to print the modified NYLON 608 bearing as seen in the Instructable
http://www.instructables.com/id/Combination-CNC-Machine-and-3D-Printer/

These files are for technical discussions only, as they are modified from the original "Printable 608 Ball Bearing" as released by "TheRooster" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4676
The design was modified to accommodate a 0.250â€ center hole rather than the metric hole. It was also modified to accommodate the cooling gradient associated with NYLON.
If you look closely at the photo, youâ€™ll note a few dropped threads at the top of the outer shell. These were outside of the bearing raceway, however an investigation of the top arc should indicate that it exceeds the 45-degree rule.
The seam on the inner raceway is a function of Z axis stepping. A slight touch of a soldering iron smoothed this out.
The bearingâ€™s final usage is for a â€œPre-Programmed Time-lapse Roving Cameraâ€ where bearings are needed for an over-all smooth movement along with a percentage of gear damping that the NYLON provides.
The bearings in the photo are made by perimeter only with no equivalent 45 degree fill. (Just a lot of circles). The end use will require the unit to support 8-10 lbs spread over 4 bearings.
While the final usage RPM is very low, the bearings have been tested at 2,400 RPM for 15+min. With no lubrication, there was a temperature rise of +8 degrees.
Vibration was negligible up to about 2,000 RPM as it became obvious that the inner seam needed more touch-up for higher RPMs.
The parts were not printed on the same run. Inner part first, then Y axis offset and then the outer shell.

title: Sparkler Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A simple and effective way to use Sparklers and create your own Mini Fireworks Display...

Designed at the request of another Thingiverse member (for use during 4th of July Celebrations) this Sparkler Holder will hold up to 27 Sparklers over three levels, with each level on a different angle, plus a centre Sparkler in the top. This lets you insert a full packet all at one time then light them sequentially / progressively or all at once (if you have an effective way of lighting lot's of Sparklers quickly).

The design features an internal retainer to locate the Sparklers so they stay at a similar angle as others on the same level as well as keeping the hot / burning part well clear of the holder itself so it won't melt or burn. The length of the Sparklers wire holder end entering the sparkler Holder is a maximum of approx. 45mm.

This is an easy print 75mm in diameter and 100mm tall that's hollow up the centre (apart from the retainer) so doesn't use a lot of filament... print one and reuse it lots of times in years to come.

Please refer to the instructions and images for additional information and please post images of your Sparkler Holder/s in use for other members to see.

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator+

Doesn't Matter

No

Standard / 0.20mm

Notes:

Easy print...

Just insert your Sparklers...

Make sure you insert your Sparklers so they align above the designed in retainer plate / disk. This will keep the Sparklers in position and at a similar angle as all other Sparklers inserted on the same level.

This is a work in progress; an additional version with a positive retainer is in development to hold the phone in place even when mounted at extreme angles.

author: AdrianMankovecky

description.text: Yet another one of these things to hold one end of the Y-axis belt for Prusa Mendel. It is designed to have a low profile and does not bend the belt.

Print the base part, and the slider either for T5 or T2.5. I have only tested the T2.5 live, but it is probably the most challenging.
As it's name implies the slider should slide freely within the base. It can be sanded to fit.
Pass a 20mm M3 bolt through the hole in the end of the base, and screw a nut on it. It's a little fiddly, but easy enough. Only screw the bolt in the width of the nut, and then pull it back until the nut is in the nut trap.
Then bolt the base in place at the end of the lower plate. Pass the belt through it, and lay it in the slider. Make sure the dimple in the slider is facing the bolt, because it has extra plastic to take the pressure.
Draw the slider back into the base as far as it goes and attach the other end of the belt with the usual components, pulling it snug tight around the idler and drive gear.
The photos should show the sequence (except that it is not bolted down during assembly).
Further tension can be achieved by tightening the bolt. A hex head bolt is best because you can use a ball drive and get a little off centre, out from under the belt.

A hanger shelf for test probes and other cables. Improved by slanting the top so that the cables slide back not off.  
This hanger can be customized by changing the number of slots, the depth of the hanger, the height of the back, the slot width, etc. Just change the variables at the beginning of the code and let it space the slots and put in mounting holes.  
The photo with cables is of a smaller (7 slot) non-slanted version.
Pretty simple to make. I used 2 shells and 25% infill at .20 height.

description.text:
This is a extruder light for the Anet A6 to illuminate the printhead while printing.
The design was influenced by the extruder light by the User 'Apers'
(design is not online anymore on Thingiverse, i don't know why)
and has a few improvements.
The part has holes for zipties to hold the LED cables in place.
Make sure to align the position of the LED strip cable (flush with the printed piece) to prevent the cable to catch on the frame when moving to the most-right part of the bed.
The part itself is not touching the frame at any point and the whole print volume can be used
(if the cable sits flush with the printed part).
The part has been tested in ABS, but should work flawless in PLA aswell (not tested).
If there are any issues with this model please let me know in the comments.
Happy printing.

remixed_from.author: lkiesow
remixed_from.title: Canon EF Mount for Telescope v2

description.text: First design! An adapter to connect my Canon 7D to my Graflex RB 5X4 and my Graflex Speed Graphic 5X4. Fits both my old cameras as well as the 7D. While it does work, it has its limits, very hard to focus on the RB due to the shift in focal plane and vastly reduced "sensor" size. The speed graphic has a more moveable front standard, so its a bit more workable, though it has to be pushed back almost all the way. I may try and design a recessed lensboard for the RB to compensate.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Variable, lower (0.30ish) for cone, higher (0.15ish) for mount fins.

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Sli3r prusa edition said I needed supports, but I went ahead without them and it worked ok.

I got the idea from this design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:988484) but I shoot canon, and the board portion was slightly smaller than my older cameras needed. I played around with modifying david_de_stras's design to fit my gear, but ended up just using it as a rough pattern and designing from scratch in tinkercad.

I chopped the bottom off of this telescope adapter (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2328732) and used its canon lens mount, which fits into my 7D perfectly (nicely done lkiesow!).

description.text:
Tired of a hard drive that would cause my entire desk to resonate and amplify the sound significantly, I designed this acoustic separation mount for it. Measurements are roughly based on the following design: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1566237

This will accept any 3.5" drive, and I have found it to have reduced volumes to close to imperceptible over fan noise and has completely eliminated all vibration/resonance issues.

Uses 2x Staedtler eraser refills (cut evenly into two sections) with a radis of 7.4mm; these should be available for a few dollars from a stationery retailer.

comments.text:
Ah, WD Black, I have a 2TB version of this rattlebox. Without isolation this thing gives up to 40db of noise in some cases.
Ended up suspending mine with rubber bands, but now it takes up two 5.25 drive bays.
Do You know if it's possible to modify your design to fit in a single 5.25 bay? Maybe have those erasers tilted 45 degrees, and the bottom part to be with horizontal holes?
comments.author: NotEnoughCheese

comments.text: They're offensively loud, hey!  I guess it would all come down to the minimum length of the erasers that would still provide dampening - I suspect that there needs to be a degree of lateral movement to aid in noise reduction.

author: orangeteacher

description.text:
This is a fidget spinner that was designed to not use any purchased bearings. It uses an embedded gear bearing for the center bearing and 6 US nickels for the outer weights. (Hence the 30-Cent title.)

The center bearing will require a little finesse in order to free it up, but you should be able to get it to spin fairly free if you are careful. Also, it spins better vertically than horizontally due to the weight of the spinner putting thrust load on the bearing. My plans are to make a center grip that also limits the side-to-side movement of the bearing with as little friction as possible. In the meantime, if anyone else has any ideas feel free to experiment!

I designed the outer caps to resemble the look of normal bearings, but let the center part of the nickels show through. Once you put the nickels inside, use a couple drops of glue to hold the caps on and encapsulate the nickels inside.

YouTube link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8hJpunvQmgk&sns=em

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%
Use a small screwdriver or similar to gently start freeing up each small gear. Once most of them move slightly you should be able to start spinning. The more they are used the better they spin.

comments.text: how long does it spin for?
comments.author: kksweet123

comments.text: There is a video link attached showing my son spinning his.  It's not necessarily as good as a steel or ceramic bearing, but it works pretty well.  The more you play with it, the better it gets.
comments.author: kksweet123

comments.text:
I just waited for this adaptation! Nice.
What tolerance did you use?
Some printers can handle 0.2mm and less, but mine needs about 0.3-0.4mm
comments.author: waldamore

comments.text: The tolerance used was 0.15 in this case.  You can try lowering your extrusion percentage if your slicer has that option.  I used to have problems printing geared things where everything would be stuck together until I started experimenting with extrusion percentage.  Once I lowered it to 82% everything started printing the right size.
comments.author: waldamore

comments.text: Which parts are you supposed to break apart in the center to get it to spin?
comments.author: CarnegieMuseum

comments.text: I take a small jewelers screwdriver and GENTLY move a few of the small gears until you can start turning it by hand.  Once you get it to turn by hand just keep spinning it until it loosens up.
comments.author: CarnegieMuseum

Most overhangs should then do not need supports.

title: Wall-mounted cat food silo with dispenser

description.text:
This is a silo which I created to store the food for my cats as they always bit open the plastic bags the food is normally stored in. However as the whole assembly is very strong, you may use it for any other granular material.
I had narrow boundaries for my design as you can see in the pictures attached.
The design works so you can hook the silo into the upper wall mount for normal use. If you need to refill it, unhook it from the upper wall mount and silde the pin of the funnel part into the lower wall mount.

I created this silo based on a conventional plastic air ventilation pipe (220x90 mm)
https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00I3GT17G/ref=s9_dcacsd_dcoop_bw_c_x_1_w
For the window I used conventional acrylic glass from my hardware store.

print_settings.Notes:: Use supports only for the Mains Box Full. Always check your preview if the supports are configured adequately.

description.text:
This is a casing for a built-in mains wall socket that can be found in most mainland European countries. I had such a socket lying around but needed a box to mount it on the wall instead of in the wall.

You basically have two options: Either you print the full box "Mains Box Full", but then you need support for the rims. Or you print the "Main Box" and the "Box Rim" separately. You can then glue that on but in my case it had a tight fit with the socket so I could screw it all together.

I know there are tons of different sockets out there. Therefore I have included the sources. Use them or be inspired to create one for your own type of socket.

Printer:

Custom Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.5 mm nozzle, 0.2 mm layer height

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Use supports only for the Mains Box Full. Always check your preview if the supports are configured adequately.

Insert M3 nuts

Put three M3 nuts in the back of the box.

Position the Box

Screw the box to the wall using the two inner holes.

Wire it

Switch of your electricity for safety. Insert your sockets and connect the wires. Screw the socket with 4 M3 screws into the box. Add the rim (if you printed it separately).

Add cover

Attach the cover plate. Now turn on the electricity again and you're done.

comments.text: PLEASE be very careful! Electrical boxes are meant to contain the sparks and heat from shorting connections. PLA and other filaments are highly flammable and would NOT make suitable electrical boxes for main line voltage!

title: Tulip flatpack vase
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Laser cut vase that's a slot together configuration designed for 4mm material such as Eurolite Poplar plywood.

There are only two different lasercut pieces in this design: Petal x 8 and Ring x 2. The petals are slotted into the rings and are held apart by a test tube. The 150mm x 25mm glass test tube makes the vase hold rigid, so there is no need for glue.
Because there are only two different laser cut components in this design, it's very easy to adjust the dimensions of the slots for different material thicknesses.

author: AustinSaintAubin

description.text:
This is a parametric version of the 5-slot cable tensioner by IvanOwen thing:232291.  I thought his design was excellent.  I needed a version, however, with just 4 tuning rods rather 5.  I also didn't have an M2 tap or the correct length of M2 screws.  Since the prosthetic hand I am making is for an adult, using the larger M3 screws was not a problem.  I made one of these tuners and found it was very strong.  
Updated on 4/17/2014 -  I have added springs to the back of the screws in the block to allow some better ability to grasp objects and continued motion after full closure.  To accommodate that, I slightly changed some of the dimensions and added a shell to cover the springs.

Either use the OpenSCAD file and modify the parameters, or use Customizer to create the needed stl file.  You can create either the tuner rods, the tuner block, or both.  The block portion does not include any mount - it is just the tuning block.  Either create the stl and then create a mashup of it with your chosen mount, or include the OpenSCAD file into the file for the mount.  The block currently prints on end because it is stronger that way.  That might work for some mounts, but not for others.  It should print fine if you rotate it to print flat instead of on end.

This is a test for testing an idea I came up with while struggling with the raft. What this test does is to print a raftless cylinder with a one layer thick base. Unlike the ordinary raft, the base is to be trimmed instead of detaching. In this way, we have the quality bottom of a raftless print and the strong grips as if printing with raft. The most interesting thing is the thin base behave almost like a thin sheet of metal. If you keeps folding it back and forth along the object silhouette, the base will break precisely at the silhouette leaving a clean shiny bottom; and you can do it with bare hands, no tools needed. (See http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LQHEhPh2ZOA)

The printed object with a one layer thick thin base:
http://www.thingiverse.com/image:139954 The process to remove the thin base by folding the thin base back and
forth: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LQHEhPh2ZOA The printed object after the thin base removed:
http://www.thingiverse.com/image:139956 Instructions 1) Add a rectangular box to the bottom of your object with a comfortable margin, where its height is exactly your layer height ( in my case 0.3 mm ). 2) Calibrate your z-axis, such that when you moving a paper in between the nozzle and the platform, you feels a little bit tension (instead of moving easily). 3) Change your setting to disable the default raft
Raft / Base / Base Layers (integer): 0
Raft / Interface / Interface Layers (integer): 0 4) Change your setting to print an object first layer that is
thin, smooth and watertight. The setting for that could be different for different machines. I just includes mine here for a reference only, and I'm using black ABS plastic.
Raft / Object First Layer / Infill Feed Rate: .25
Raft / Object First Layer / Perimeter Feed Rate: .25
Raft / Object First Layer / Flow Rate: 0.20625
Raft / Object First Layer / Nozzle Lift : 0
Temperature / Object first layer infill : 225
Temperature / Object first layer perimeter : 225 The STL file and the OpenSCAD file (gcadabb.stl and gcadabb.scad) are also included for testing. If you are printing with layer height other than 0.3 mm, you will need to edit the file gcadabb.scad to adjust the height of the thin base. The whole story I have my Thingomatic HBP MK7 two weeks ago. The printer works great except the raft. It turns out tweaking the raft setting to meet my expectation is almost impossible. In the raft setting, we can alther the base, the interface and the object first layer settings. By althering these settings, we are literally changing to what extend the object first layer fusing with the interface. Fusing too much, the object will be very difficult to remove from the raft but the bottom layer looks better. Fusing too little, the object can be detached from the raft easily but the bottom layer looks like a mess. The worst thing is a middle ground to suit both simply does not exist. (Here is how do I know there is no such a middle ground... http://www.thingiverse.com/image:139951) Well well, printing the bottom layer correct is not just for the sake of perfection. It is a necessarity for even just an average print because any deformation at the bottom layer will propagate upward for many many layers to come (that's FDM). In this sense, we can only choose the raft that is very difficult to be removed. I used to remove raft with a cutter, and accidentally cut myself for a few times. That's why I really hate raft. Printing raftless could be a solution. Unfortunately, it only works for smaller objects with a big fat bottom layer. For objects with a curved long narrow bottom layer, printing raftless is not providing enough grips to the platform, and, more than likely, the object will be detached while printing. Raft is doomed to be diffcult to remove. Diffcult it is, let's don't have it removed. That's why I substitute the default raft with a thin base. The thin base is a one layer high rectangluar box. The height must be exactly the same as your layer height. Any value smaller than that, ReplicatorG will simply igore the box completely. If configured correctly, the thin base will have a smooth surface on the top, a shiny surface at the bottom, a watertight filling, the strength of a thin sheet of metal and a semi transparent look (even with black ABS). (See the video http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LQHEhPh2ZOA) Be reminded that being watertight is essential for the adhesion to platform, please make sure your thin base does have a watertight filling. If the area of the thin base is the same as the default raft, the grips offered should be the same. If you keeps folding the thin base back and forth along the object silhouette, the thin base will break precisely at the silhouette leaving a clean shiny bottom. (Be patient, just folding back and forth, don't tear, it will break.) However, the down side is you have to modifify your 3D model on your own, which can be tricky sometimes. I have already using this method for my printing for quite a while now. Ocasionally, there will be some jaggy silhouette when I try to break the thin base from the object (especially for features with sharp changes). In this case, I still need to use my cutter; please don't be disappointed, fixing a perimeter is still way easier than fixing the whole surface. Best regards,
Gary

comments.text: The curling of the skirts can actually be eliminated easily.  It happens because your platform is not level agaisnt the nozzle.  Try to calibrate your platform as level as possible, the situation will be improved by quite an extend.  Besides the calibration, you can also increase the flow rate.  This can give you a bigger tolerance to the calibration.  However, increasing flow rate is going to cause more problems than it can solve.  Therefore, calibrating your platform to absolutly level to nozzle is the only true solution.

description.text:
Edit 6/17/2017: If you hate hearts, but love Batman, here's a 1966 Batman bokeh lens cover I made, in memory of Adam West who passed this last week:

Edit 6/16/2017: Uploaded a replacement version of the cover. The old version went a little overboard with fillets, so the handle snapped off easily. Only one person downloaded the original version (sorry!), but my hope is, that one person is going to be like "Handle? That's the one thing I hated about this design. It just snaps off? Awesome!" Otherwise, hopefully that person will download this new version, and the handle is not only twice as thick (4mm versus 2mm!) but it's connected 100% around its edges. Whoo!

To quote GlaDOS from Portal:

When I said "deadly neurotoxin," the "deadly" was in massive sarcasm quotes. I could take a bath in this stuff. Put it on cereal, rub it right into my eyes. Honestly, it's not deadly at all... to me. You, on the other hand, are going to find its deadliness... a lot less funny.

I made a thing. Really! I was looking at the following thing, and I printed it!

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2142662

It was fantastic for making a heart-shaped topping on coffee - or on anything, really! I wouldn't recommend using it on, or near, hot lava. It might melt.

I then looked at it, and it looked a whole heck of a lot like this thing I made out of cardboard and duct tape years ago, to tape over the end of my high-end DSLR to make pin point lights turn into heart shapes!

https://www.flickr.com/photos/theamarand/3164779001/

Of course, the version I made back in 2009 was crude, and cut-out with scissors by a not very dexterous "old." (That's me.)

Then, a few years later, my wife saved a baby bird!

https://www.flickr.com/photos/theamarand/17402580262/

But seriously, that has nothing to do with this Thing, except I love her, and this Thing helps you make hearts with your camera.

So my subconcious mind put two-and-two (or one-and-one?) together, and decided that I should probably sit-down and revisit my original, sticky (duct tape is super sticky!), poorly-designed, poorly-executed bokeh machine.

This Thing is the result.

Although the Coffee Stencil may look very similar to this thing, I can assure you, I worked directly from an original sketch in Fusion 360, measured the lengths and widths and diameters of my lens and iris using digital calipers, and then went to work.

If you have the current model of the Canon 100mm macro lens shown in this picture, and you print this at either medium (200 µ) or maybe even low (300 u), you should get a decent layer height with "ridges" which, apparently, enjoy holding this cap onto the end of my standard UV filter without any tape or other shim. I was shocked! I measured twice, printed once, and it fit like a glove. Not too loose, not too tight. Your mileage may vary. My UV filter is by a company B+W, but I'm guessing a metal, 68mm screw-on filter for this lens is fairly similar specs-wise, seeing as most of them let you stack filters on top of filters.

Here's what I'm offering:

1) If you love the heart, but for some reason, have a different size lens or whatever, just send me pictures of the end of your lens/filter, give me specs, the make and model of the lens and the filter, and I'll try to work something up for you. If it's a heart bokeh, I will simply add it here as a new version of the cover, with a new name, and the same or similar heart. Please let me know if your lens iris is significantly smaller or larger than the average size, because I think the heart needs to be larger/smaller based on that. Here's a good reference:

(Just search for "bokeh" on the page, and read up!)
http://www.alex-buono.com/how-we-did-it-snl-titles-sequence/

2) If you have this lens, and you want a different symbol, please let me know what symbol you'd like. I can make a square. I can make a circle. I could probably make an oval. If given enough time, I could make various stars. But yeah, just come up with an idea, and maybe sketch it out. If you're crafty, send me some form of vector art, and I can then tweak it in Adobe Illustrator, and size it appropriately for this thing. For any non-heart related bokeh items, I will create a new "Thing" and reference them against each other. As this is the first, there will be no referencing...yet.

3) If you want, say, a dog paw print bokeh, and you have a different lens, we'll have to do both 1 and 2 above.

To summarize: New bokeh gets a new Thing, new lens/filter alone sticks with the same bokeh Thing. Yay!

Please ask questions, submit comments, and think about submitting an "I Made One," especially if you want to share pictures and words of your success stories, and/or want me to tweak something. It helps me to visualize what your issue is if you share pictures, and "I Made One" helps facilitate that.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

This printed like a dream. Decided to go with a neutral white PLA, but I imagine black or dark-gray (neutral) PLA would work better/best. Sometimes white is too reflective for photography purposes. Your mileage may vary.

How to Assemble

Stick on the end of your UV filter that should, hopefully, be screwed onto the end of your lens. Everyone with a lens capable of attaching a filter, should always have a UV filter to protect the lens. If you don't have a UV filter, or some sort of filter, this will probably not work for you.

I measured the outside diameter of my filter using digital calipers, and I created the inside diameter ever so slightly smaller (maybe 0.25mm?) so it would fit snugly.

You may, or may not, need to clean the part up a little before using, but it's not a cosmetic part by any means, so you only need to worry about items that are interfering with the bokeh "window," or the connection to the filter. That's it!

How to Use

I just realized, I never explained how you'd go ahead and use these. I guess I could totally share a link that got me started years ago....

http://www.diyphotography.net/diy_create_your_own_bokeh/

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

Super simple to make in Fusion 360. Sliced with Simplify3D, and that was it.

It was a sketch, with a circle, and then another offset circle by 2mm. I then added a little handle with a nail hole, so you can "hook" it if you're one of those organizational freaks like me. One day, I will have a wall or two filled with peg board, and these will all be hooked on the peg board. Hooray!

I raised the center by a few mm along with the hook. I then raised the outer "circle" by 4mm above that, and that, my friends, is a lens cover!

I then designed a heart using the basic two-circles with a center line, two lines down to a point from the lower tangents and, bam, you have a heart.

http://autodesk.blogs.com/between_the_lines/2012/02/valentines-day-geometry.html

Punch that 100% through, and call it a day. Hooray!

Custom Lens and Bokeh

Does your lens differ from my lens? Want a different bokeh opening?

If you know exactly what you want (inside diameter and depth) as far as the part that connects to your lens, just let me know. It's best if you sketch it out, and I have been enjoying the "I Made One" feature. If you download the version of the cover that seems like it would be the closest fit and try it, that's a great first step. If it's too big or too small, just take pictures of it close to the lens, sketch on a piece of paper, and share all of that data in your "I Made One" area, that way we can talk back and forth specifically against your version, until it's working perfectly for you and we can name it with the make and model of your lens/camera, plus your (user)name if you'd like!

title: OctoPi webcam holder (Logitech C270) for Prusa i3 MK2 with cable chain

description.text:
This is a webcam holder for a Logitech C270 to be mounted to the right X-axis carriage of a Prusa i3 MK2(s). The design does not require any changes on the printer, its simple plug-and-play by using an existing whole in the carrige. I got this design idea from derfred.

To mount the logitech to the holder the orginal srew can be used. The lower clip can simply be clipped to the frame.

The cable chains I used are a design from Aaron Yourk
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8r558hYwxKj
I used 19 chain links. Note that you have to alternate their orientation (see pictures) in order to achieve the desired bending.

Due to the short distance between the nozzle and the camera, the focus of the Logitech C270 needs to be adjusted. To do that I used the focus ring by TheChrisP.
Of course also other cameras can be principally used with this design, as only the camera holder is affected by the different designs of the webcam mounts.

description.text:
A set of speakers (desktop) I designed using the teardrop back ported construction. They were designed for the Dayton Audio PS95-8 3-1/2" Point Source Full Range Driver 8 Ohm and tuned accordingly.
The speakers print in two parts which twist lock together. For the most part they print without support though you will need it for the main body which prints driver end down. Your printer will need to be fairly well tuned in order for the twist lock to work straight off the bed - otherwise a little sanding will be needed. The tolerances are deliberately low because the lock needs to be tight.
They have holes for the pegs towards the back of the speaker and I personally placed accoustifill (essentially stuffing) inside mine (allowing of course for airflow out the port) to give a little more depth and richness.
I am very happy with the final sound after driver break in.

Mine were printed in Hatchbox woodfil and then given 6 coats of satin lacquer after sanding ALMOST smooth. I wanted some print lines left. You do them how you like. I do feel however the softer wood filament was of a benefit to the sound.

comments.text: Sorry for another (somewhat dumb) question: Other than the 3d printed parts & the drivers, what else will I need?
comments.author: lowfuel

comments.text: You will need some short speaker wire - or at least some medium heavy gauge wire. I also like the accoustifil product but in a pinch you could use the very light stuffing they use for chairs. You will also need the pegs for the speaker inputs and any associated cables to go from your musical device of choice.
comments.author: lowfuel

comments.text: Excellent. Thanks much! I'm printing speaker #1 right now.
comments.author: Framingr

comments.text: Awesome - let me know how they work out for you. As mine break in I feel they sound even better. One word of advice make sure you wire up the speakers and remember which is positive and negative correctly (the pegs should truly represent the polarity they are attached to) If you cross wire one of the speakers you will lose a lot of base.
comments.author: lowfuel

comments.text: What infill % did you use? Any other print setting tips?
comments.author: lowfuel

comments.text: 3 shells - 10% infill. I find that when I plan to sand something the shells are more important than the infill. In this case the walls are not very wide so its not necessary to pack them full of infill
comments.author: lowfuel

comments.text: Thanks!

description.text:
I extended the original design by designzuk to include mounts for a raspberry pi and 3 channel relay.

The quality of the modifications are not on par with the original. However, it worked well enough for my needs so I thought it might be useful for anyone with a similar setup.

A few notes:

  • Only the usb and ethernet port are exposed for the pi.
  • I am powering the pi through the GPIO pins. If you want to use the micro usb power input you will probably need a 90 degree usb cable or adapter as space between the pi and the mainboard is somewhat limited.
  • This sticks out quite a bit from the back of the printer, so it might not be a good option if space is an issue.

title: Intex Ultra Frame Pool Cover Clip

description.text:
This is a clip to secure the cover of an Intex Ultra Frame above ground swimming pool.

I got fed up with coming home on windy days (or getting up after windy nights) to find the pool cover submerged in the middle of the pool, so designed this clip to help secure the cover to the pool frame.

The shape of the Ultra Frame top beam is quite complex, so this took a bit of trial and error, and honestly, I gave up fine tuning it when it was 'good enough'. It seems to hold the cover quite securely.

Update: We've had quite a few wet and windy days now, and the clips really do the job! I have one on every other frame beam, and haven't had to fish the cover out of the pool once.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed in ABS for the added strength and flexibility.
I'd recommend a quick clean up and sand to remove any sharp edges to avoid damage to the pool cover.

title: VW Jetta Wagon Privacy Shade Repair Pieces

description.text:
These pieces will fix a broken cargo shade in a MKIV VW Jetta Wagon. May also fit the Audi A4 Wagon if it uses the same shade. May fit the Passat as well. What I know for sure is it works in my 2003 Jetta Wagon.

What happens is the plastic pegs inside get brittle, break from the spring tension, and the shade hangs limp. This fix spreads the load over a larger area of the printed replacement and should take some stress off of the plastic end caps.

I made this in TinkerCad over the course of an hour or so. It went through a few revisions before I was satisfied with how it turned out. Half eyeballing and half measuring with some cheap digital calipers.

You absolutely want to print this in something sturdy like PETG, ABS, or Nylon. It is small enough where printing 3 layers should not create enough area for infill.

How to fix your sun shade:

Print the pieces, which are a left and right side. Remove the shade from the car and pull the end caps off. They will just pull off because the broken part is what holds them on the shade. Unscrew the security Torx screws and pop out the broken off plastic.

Repair any cracks with a strong glue like a two part epoxy or JB Weld.

Enlarge the holes just enough for the printed parts to slide in place and you may want to glue them in place. Scrape off the rubberized coating if you are gluing. They don't seem to need to be glued as the pegs keep them from moving.

Now you may need to get longer screws as I haven't tried the design that I have uploaded but the original screws will probably be long enough. If not you should get longer screws by about 1/8". Countersunk head wood screws would be sufficient.

Here's the tricky part: Roll the shade back up into the roller. Take the right side piece (with the button) and screw it on first. Push the roll out a little bit so the right side endpiece can spin and wind it about 11 or 12 times clockwise. Push the aluminum channel back in to the end piece and screw the other side down. You should be able to grab one side and pull it out smoothly and have it retract. Sometimes the shade binds up because it was rolled up with slack in it but after the first time it should be smooth.

Since the width is increased, you will have a tight fit putting it back in the car. I would suggest trying to ease it in with a flat blade screwdriver gently pushing the trim out as you push down the end cap. Be careful, the rest of the plastic is just as brittle.
